column2: CHAPTER 4
column3: CHAPTER four

column2: Stephen Gresham was in his early sixties, but he could have still worn his World War I uniform without anything giving at the seams, and buckled the old Sam Browne at the same hole.
column3: Stephen Gresham was in his early sixties, but he could have still worn his World War one uniform without anything giving at the seams, and buckled the old Sam Browne at the same hole.

column2: As Rand entered, he rose from behind his desk and advanced, smiling cordially.
column3: As Rand entered, he rose from behind his desk and advanced, smiling cordially.

column2: Why, hello, Jeff! he greeted the detective, grasping his hand heartily. "You haven't been around for months.
column3: Why, hello, Jeff! he greeted the detective, grasping his hand heartily. "You haven't been around for months.

column2: What have you been doing, and why don't you come out to Rosemont to see us?
column3: What have you been doing, and why don't you come out to Rosemont to see us?

column2: Dot and Irene were wondering what had become of you."
column3: Dot and Irene were wondering what had become of you."

column2: I'm afraid I've been neglecting too many of my old friends lately, Rand admitted, sitting down and getting his pipe out.
column3: I'm afraid I've been neglecting too many of my old friends lately, Rand admitted, sitting down and getting his pipe out.

column2: Been busy as the devil.	Been busy as the devil.
column3: true

column2: Fact is, it was business that finally brought me around here.
column3: Fact is, it was business that finally brought me around here.

column2: I understand that you and some others are forming a pool to buy the Lane Fleming collection."
column3: I understand that you and some others are forming a pool to buy the Lane Fleming collection."

column2: Yes! Gresham became enthusiastic.
column3: Yes! Gresham became enthusiastic.

column2: Want in on it?	Want in on it?
column3: true

column2: I'm sure the others would be glad to have you in with us.
column3: I'm sure the others would be glad to have you in with us.

column2: We're going to need all the money we can scrape together, with this damned Rivers bidding against us."
column3: We're going to need all the money we can scrape together, with this damned Rivers bidding against us."

column2: I'm afraid you will, at that, Stephen, Rand told him.
column3: I'm afraid you will, at that, Stephen, Rand told him.

column2: And not necessarily on account of Rivers.	And not necessarily on account of Rivers.
column3: true

column2: You see, the Fleming estate has just employed me to expertize the collection and handle the sale for them." Rand got his pipe lit and drawing properly.
column3: You see, the Fleming estate has just employed me to expertize the collection and handle the sale for them." Rand got his pipe lit and drawing properly.

column2: I hate doing this to you, but you know how it is.
column3: I hate doing this to you, but you know how it is.

column2: Oh, of course.	Oh, of course.
column3: false

column2: I should have known they'd get somebody like you in to sell the collection for them.
column3: I should have known they'd get somebody like you in to sell the collection for them.

column2: Humphrey Goode isn't competent to handle that.
column3: Humphrey Goode isn't competent to handle that.

column2: What we were all afraid of was a public auction at some sales-gallery."
column3: What we were all afraid of was a public auction at some sales gallery."

column2: Rand shook his head.
column3: Rand shook his head.

column2: Worst thing they could do; a collection like that would go for peanuts at auction.	Worst thing they could do; a collection like that would go for peanuts at auction.
column3: true

column2: Remember the big sales in the twenties?...
column3: Remember the big sales in the twenties?...

column2: Why, here; I'm going to be in Rosemont, staying at the Fleming place, working on the collection, for the next week or so.
column3: Why, here; I'm going to be in Rosemont, staying at the Fleming place, working on the collection, for the next week or so.

column2: I suppose your crowd wouldn't want to make an offer until I have everything listed, but I'd like to talk to your associates, in a group, as soon as possible."
column3: I suppose your crowd wouldn't want to make an offer until I have everything listed, but I'd like to talk to your associates, in a group, as soon as possible."

column2: Well, we all know pretty much what's in the collection, Gresham said. "We were neighbors of his, and collectors are a gregarious lot.
column3: Well, we all know pretty much what's in the collection, Gresham said. "We were neighbors of his, and collectors are a gregarious lot.

column2: But we aren't anxious to make any premature offers.
column3: But we aren't anxious to make any premature offers.

column2: We don't want to offer more than we have to, and at the same time, we don't want to underbid and see the collection sold elsewhere."
column3: We don't want to offer more than we have to, and at the same time, we don't want to underbid and see the collection sold elsewhere."

column2: No, of course not. Rand thought for a moment.
column3: No, of course not. Rand thought for a moment.

column2: Tell you what; I'll give you and your friends the best break I can in fairness to my clients.	Tell you what; I'll give you and your friends the best break I can in fairness to my clients.
column3: false

column2: I'm not obliged to call for sealed bids, or anything like that, so when I've heard from everybody, I'll give you a chance to bid against the highest offer in hand.
column3: I'm not obliged to call for sealed bids, or anything like that, so when I've heard from everybody, I'll give you a chance to bid against the highest offer in hand.

column2: If you want to top it, you can have the collection for any kind of an overbid that doesn't look too suspiciously nominal."
column3: If you want to top it, you can have the collection for any kind of an overbid that doesn't look too suspiciously nominal."

column2: Why, Jeff, I appreciate that, Gresham said.
column3: Why, Jeff, I appreciate that, Gresham said.

column2: I think you're entirely within your rights, but naturally, we won't mention this outside.	I think you're entirely within your rights, but naturally, we won't mention this outside.
column3: true

column2: I can imagine Arnold Rivers, for instance, taking a very righteous view of such an arrangement."
column3: I can imagine Arnold Rivers, for instance, taking a very righteous view of such an arrangement."

column2: Yes, so can I. Of course, if he'd call me a crook, I'd take that as a compliment, Rand said.
column3: Yes, so can i Of course, if he'd call me a crook, I'd take that as a compliment, Rand said.

column2: I wonder if I could meet your group, say tomorrow evening?	I wonder if I could meet your group, say tomorrow evening?
column3: true

column2: I want to be in a position to assure the Fleming family and Humphrey Goode that you're all serious and responsible."
column3: I want to be in a position to assure the Fleming family and Humphrey Goode that you're all serious and responsible."

column2: Well, we're very serious about it, Gresham replied, "and I think we're all responsible.
column3: Well, we're very serious about it, Gresham replied, "and I think we're all responsible.

column2: You can look us up, if you wish.
column3: You can look us up, if you wish.

column2: Besides myself, there is Philip Cabot, of Cabot, Joyner & Teale, whom you know, and Adam Trehearne, who's worth about a half-million in industrial shares, and Colin MacBride, who's vice president in charge of construction and maintenance for Edison-Public Power & Light, at about twenty thousand a year, and Pierre Jarrett and his fiancee, Karen Lawrence.
column3: Besides myself, there is Philip Cabot, of Cabot, Joyner and Teale, whom you know, and Adam Trehearne, who's worth about a half million in industrial shares, and Colin MacBride, who's vice president in charge of construction and maintenance for Edison Public Power and Light, at about twenty thousand a year, and Pierre Jarrett and his fiancee, Karen Lawrence.

column2: Pierre was a Marine captain, invalided home after being wounded on Peleliu; he writes science-fiction for the pulps.
column3: Pierre was a Marine captain, invalided home after being wounded on Peleliu; he writes science fiction for the pulps.

column2: Karen has a little general-antique business in Rosemont.
column3: Karen has a little general antique business in Rosemont.

column2: They intend using their share of the collection, plus such culls and duplicates as the rest of us can consign to them, to go into the arms business, with a general-antique sideline, which Karen can manage while Pierre's writing....
column3: They intend using their share of the collection, plus such culls and duplicates as the rest of us can consign to them, to go into the arms business, with a general antique sideline, which Karen can manage while Pierre's writing....

column2: Tell you what; I'll call a meeting at my place tomorrow evening, say at eight thirty.
column3: Tell you what; I'll call a meeting at my place tomorrow evening, say at eight thirty.

column2: That suit you?"
column3: That suit you?"

column2: That, Rand agreed, would be all right.
column3: That, Rand agreed, would be all right.

column2: Gresham asked him how recently he had seen the Fleming collection.
column3: Gresham asked him how recently he had seen the Fleming collection.

column2: About two years ago; right after I got back from Germany.	About two years ago; right after I got back from Germany.
column3: true

column2: You remember, we went there together, one evening in March."
column3: You remember, we went there together, one evening in March."

column2: Yes, that's right.	Yes, that's right.
column3: true

column2: We didn't have time to see everything," Gresham said. "My God, Jeff!
column3: We didn't have time to see everything," Gresham said. "My God, Jeff!

column2: Twenty-five wheel locks!
column3: Twenty five wheel locks!

column2: Ten snaphaunces.
column3: Ten snaphaunces.

column2: And every imaginable kind of flintlock--over a hundred U.S. Martials, including the 1818 Springfield, all the S. North types, a couple of Virginia Manufactory models, and--he got this since the last time you saw the collection--a real Rappahannock Forge flintlock.
column3: And every imaginable kind of flintlock-over a hundred u s Martials, including the eighteen eighteen Springfield, all the s North types, a couple of Virginia Manufactory models, and-he got this since the last time you saw the collection-a real Rappahannock Forge flintlock.

column2: And about a hundred and fifty Colts, all models and most variants.
column3: And about a hundred and fifty Colts, all models and most variants.

column2: Remember that big Whitneyville Walker, in original condition?
column3: Remember that big Whitneyville Walker, in original condition?

column2: He got that one in 1924, at the Fred Hines sale, at the old Walpole Galleries.
column3: He got that one in nineteen twenty four, at the Fred Hines sale, at the old Walpole Galleries.

column2: And seven Paterson Colts, including a couple of cased sets.
column3: And seven Paterson Colts, including a couple of cased sets.

column2: And anything else you can think of.
column3: And anything else you can think of.

column2: A Hall flintlock breech-loader; an Elisha Collier flintlock revolver; a pair of Forsythe detonator-lock pistols....
column3: A Hall flintlock breech loader; an Elisha Collier flintlock revolver; a pair of Forsythe detonator lock pistols....

column2: Oh, that's a collection to end collections."
column3: Oh, that's a collection to end collections."

column2: By the way, Humphrey Goode showed me a pair of big ball-butt wheel locks, all covered with ivory inlay, Rand mentioned.
column3: By the way, Humphrey Goode showed me a pair of big ball butt wheel locks, all covered with ivory inlay, Rand mentioned.

column2: Gresham laughed heartily.
column3: Gresham laughed heartily.

column2: Aren't they the damnedest ever seen, though? he asked.
column3: Aren't they the damnedest ever seen, though? he asked.

column2: Made in Germany, about 1870 or '80, about the time arms-collecting was just getting out of the family-heirloom stage, wouldn't you say?
column3: Made in Germany, about eighteen seventy or 'eighty, about the time arms collecting was just getting out of the family heirloom stage, wouldn't you say?

column2: I'd say made in Japan, about 1920, Rand replied.
column3: I'd say made in Japan, about nineteen twenty, Rand replied.

column2: Remember, there were a couple of small human figures on each pistol, a knight and a huntsman? Did you notice that they had slant eyes? He stopped laughing, and looked at Gresham seriously.
column3: Remember, there were a couple of small human figures on each pistol, a knight and a huntsman? Did you notice that they had slant eyes? He stopped laughing, and looked at Gresham seriously.

column2: Just how much more of that sort of thing do you think I'm going to have to weed out of the collection, before I can offer it for sale? he asked.
column3: Just how much more of that sort of thing do you think I'm going to have to weed out of the collection, before I can offer it for sale? he asked.

column2: Gresham shook his head.
column3: Gresham shook his head.

column2: They're all.	They're all.
column3: true

column2: They were Lane Fleming's one false step.
column3: They were Lane Fleming's one false step.

column2: Ordinarily, Lane was a careful buyer; he must have let himself get hypnotized by all that ivory and gold, and all that documentation on crested notepaper.
column3: Ordinarily, Lane was a careful buyer; he must have let himself get hypnotized by all that ivory and gold, and all that documentation on crested notepaper.

column2: You know, Fleming's death was an undeserved stroke of luck for Arnold Rivers.
column3: You know, Fleming's death was an undeserved stroke of luck for Arnold Rivers.

column2: If he hadn't been killed just when he was, he'd have run Rivers out of the old-arms business."
column3: If he hadn't been killed just when he was, he'd have run Rivers out of the old arms business."

column2: I notice that Rivers isn't advertising in the _American Rifleman_ any more, Rand observed.
column3: I notice that Rivers isn't advertising in the underscore American Rifleman underscore any more, Rand observed.

column2: No; the National Rifle Association stopped his ad, and lifted his membership card for good measure, Gresham said.
column3: No; the National Rifle Association stopped his ad, and lifted his membership card for good measure, Gresham said.

column2: Rivers sold a rifle to a collector down in Virginia, about three years ago, while you were still occupying Germany.	Rivers sold a rifle to a collector down in Virginia, about three years ago, while you were still occupying Germany.
column3: true

column2: A fine, early flintlock Kentuck, that had been made out of a fine, late percussion Kentuck by sawing off the breech-end of the barrel, rethreading it for the breech-plug, drilling a new vent, and fitting the lock with a flint hammer and a pan-and-frizzen assembly, and shortening the fore-end to fit.
column3: A fine, early flintlock Kentuck, that had been made out of a fine, late percussion Kentuck by sawing off the breech end of the barrel, rethreading it for the breech plug, drilling a new vent, and fitting the lock with a flint hammer and a pan and frizzen assembly, and shortening the fore end to fit.

column2: Rivers has a gunsmith over at Kingsville, one Elmer Umholtz, who does all his fraudulent conversions for him.
column3: Rivers has a gunsmith over at Kingsville, one Elmer Umholtz, who does all his fraudulent conversions for him.

column2: I have an example of Umholtz's craftsmanship, myself.
column3: I have an example of Umholtz's craftsmanship, myself.

column2: The collector who bought this spurious flintlock spotted what had been done, and squawked to the Rifle Association, and to the postal authorities."
column3: The collector who bought this spurious flintlock spotted what had been done, and squawked to the Rifle Association, and to the postal authorities."

column2: Rivers claimed, I suppose, that he had gotten it from a family that had owned it ever since it was made, and showed letters signed 'D.	Rivers claimed, I suppose, that he had gotten it from a family that had owned it ever since it was made, and showed letters signed 'D.
column3: true

column2: Boone' and 'Davy Crockett' to prove it?"
column3: Boone' and 'Davy Crockett' to prove it?"

column2: No, he claimed to have gotten it in trade from some wayfaring collector, Gresham replied.
column3: No, he claimed to have gotten it in trade from some wayfaring collector, Gresham replied.

column2: He convinced Uncle Whiskers, but the N.R.A. took a slightly dimmer view of the transaction, so Rivers doesn't advertise in the _Rifleman_ any more.
column3: He convinced Uncle Whiskers, but the n r a took a slightly dimmer view of the transaction, so Rivers doesn't advertise in the underscore Rifleman underscore any more.

column2: Wasn't there some talk about Whitneyville Walker Colts that had been made out of 1848 Model Colt Dragoons? Rand asked.
column3: Wasn't there some talk about Whitneyville Walker Colts that had been made out of eighteen forty eight Model Colt Dragoons? Rand asked.

column2: Oh Lord, yes!	Oh Lord, yes!
column3: true

column2: This fellow Umholtz was practically turning them out on an assembly-line, for a while.
column3: This fellow Umholtz was practically turning them out on an assembly line, for a while.

column2: Rivers must have sold about ten of them. You know, Umholtz is a really fine gunsmith; I had him build a deer-rifle for Dot, a couple of years ago--Mexican-Mauser action, Johnson barrel, chambered for .300 Savage; Umholtz made the stock and fitted a scope-sight--it's a beautiful little rifle.
column3: Rivers must have sold about ten of them. You know, Umholtz is a really fine gunsmith; I had him build a deer rifle for Dot, a couple of years ago-Mexican Mauser action, Johnson barrel, chambered for point three zero zero Savage; Umholtz made the stock and fitted a scope sight-it's a beautiful little rifle.

column2: I hate to see him prostitute his talents the way he does by making these fake antiques for Rivers.
column3: I hate to see him prostitute his talents the way he does by making these fake antiques for Rivers.

column2: You know, he made one of these mythical heavy .44 six-shooters of the sort Colt was supposed to have turned out at Paterson in 1839 for Colonel Walker's Texas Rangers--you know, the model he couldn't find any of in 1847, when he made the real Walker Colt.
column3: You know, he made one of these mythical heavy point four four six shooters of the sort Colt was supposed to have turned out at Paterson in eighteen thirty nine for Colonel Walker's Texas Rangers-you know, the model he couldn't find any of in eighteen forty seven, when he made the real Walker Colt.

column2: That story you find in Sawyer's book."
column3: That story you find in Sawyer's book."

column2: Why, that story's been absolutely disproved, Rand said.
column3: Why, that story's been absolutely disproved, Rand said.

column2: There never was any such revolver.
column3: There never was any such revolver.

column2: Not till Umholtz made one, Gresham replied.
column3: Not till Umholtz made one, Gresham replied.

column2: Rivers sold it to,--he named a moving-picture bigshot--"for twenty-five hundred dollars.
column3: Rivers sold it to,--he named a moving picture bigshot-"for twenty five hundred dollars.

column2: His story was that he picked it up in Mexico, in 1938; traded a .38-special to some halfbreed goat-herder for it."
column3: His story was that he picked it up in Mexico, in nineteen thirty eight; traded a point three eight-special to some halfbreed goat herder for it."

column2: This fellow who bought it, now; did he see Belden and Haven's Colt book, when it came out in 1940?
column3: This fellow who bought it, now; did he see Belden and Haven's Colt book, when it came out in nineteen forty?

column2: Yes, and he was plenty burned up, but what could he do?	Yes, and he was plenty burned up, but what could he do?
column3: true

column2: Rivers was dug in behind this innocent-purchase-and-sale-in-good-faith Maginot Line of his.
column3: Rivers was dug in behind this innocent purchase and sale in good faith Maginot Line of his.

column2: You know, that bastard took me, once, just one-tenth as badly, with a fake U.S. North & Cheney Navy flintlock 1799 Model that had been made out of a French 1777 Model." The lawyer muttered obscenely.
column3: You know, that bastard took me, once, just one tenth as badly, with a fake u s North and Cheney Navy flintlock seventeen ninety nine Model that had been made out of a French seventeen seventy seven Model." The lawyer muttered obscenely.

column2: Why didn't you sue hell out of him? Rand asked.
column3: Why didn't you sue hell out of him? Rand asked.

column2: You might not have gotten anything, but you'd have given him a lot of dirty publicity. That's all Fleming was expecting to do about those wheel locks.
column3: You might not have gotten anything, but you'd have given him a lot of dirty publicity. That's all Fleming was expecting to do about those wheel locks.

column2: I'm not Fleming.	I'm not Fleming.
column3: true

column2: He could afford litigation like that; I can't.
column3: He could afford litigation like that; I can't.

column2: I want my money, and if I don't get it in cash, I'm going to beat it out of that dirty little swindler's hide," Gresham replied, an ugly look appearing on his face.
column3: I want my money, and if I don't get it in cash, I'm going to beat it out of that dirty little swindler's hide," Gresham replied, an ugly look appearing on his face.

column2: I wouldn't blame you.	I wouldn't blame you.
column3: true

column2: You could find plenty of other collectors who'd hold your coat while you were doing it," Rand told him.
column3: You could find plenty of other collectors who'd hold your coat while you were doing it," Rand told him.

column2: Then he inquired, idly: "What sort of a pistol was it that Lane Fleming is supposed to have shot himself with?"
column3: Then he inquired, idly: "What sort of a pistol was it that Lane Fleming is supposed to have shot himself with?"

column2: Gresham frowned.
column3: Gresham frowned.

column2: I really don't know; I didn't see it.	I really don't know; I didn't see it.
column3: true

column2: It's supposed to have been a Confederate Leech & Rigdon .36; you know, one of those imitation Colt Navy Models that were made in the South during the Civil War."
column3: It's supposed to have been a Confederate Leech and Rigdon point three six; you know, one of those imitation Colt Navy Models that were made in the South during the Civil War."

column2: Rand nodded.
column3: Rand nodded.

column2: He was familiar with the type.
column3: He was familiar with the type.

column2: The story is that Fleming found it hanging back of the counter at some roadside lunch-stand, along with a lot of other old pistols, and talked the proprietor into letting it go for a few dollars, Gresham continued. "It was supposed to have been loaded at the time, and went off while Fleming was working on it, at home." He shook his head.
column3: The story is that Fleming found it hanging back of the counter at some roadside lunch stand, along with a lot of other old pistols, and talked the proprietor into letting it go for a few dollars, Gresham continued. "It was supposed to have been loaded at the time, and went off while Fleming was working on it, at home." He shook his head.

column2: I can't believe that, Jeff.	I can't believe that, Jeff.
column3: true

column2: Lane Fleming would know a loaded revolver when he saw one.
column3: Lane Fleming would know a loaded revolver when he saw one.

column2: I believe he deliberately shot himself, and the family faked the accident and fixed the authorities.
column3: I believe he deliberately shot himself, and the family faked the accident and fixed the authorities.

column2: The police never made any investigation; it was handled by the coroner alone.
column3: The police never made any investigation; it was handled by the coroner alone.

column2: And our coroner, out in Scott County, is eminently fixable, if you go about it right; a pitiful little nonentity with a tremendous inferiority complex."
column3: And our coroner, out in Scott County, is eminently fixable, if you go about it right; a pitiful little nonentity with a tremendous inferiority complex."

column2: But good Lord, why? Rand demanded.
column3: But good Lord, why? Rand demanded.

column2: I never heard of Fleming having any troubles worth killing himself over.
column3: I never heard of Fleming having any troubles worth killing himself over.

column2: Gresham lowered his voice.
column3: Gresham lowered his voice.

column2: Jeff, I'm not supposed to talk about this, but the fact is that I believe Fleming was about to lose control of the Premix Company, he said.
column3: Jeff, I'm not supposed to talk about this, but the fact is that I believe Fleming was about to lose control of the Premix Company, he said.

column2: I have, well, sources of inside information. This is in confidence, so don't quote me, but certain influences were at work, inside the company, toward that end. He inspected the tip of his cigar and knocked off the ash into the tray at his elbow.
column3: I have, well, sources of inside information. This is in confidence, so don't quote me, but certain influences were at work, inside the company, toward that end. He inspected the tip of his cigar and knocked off the ash into the tray at his elbow.

column2: Lane Fleming's death is on record as accidental, Jeff.	Lane Fleming's death is on record as accidental, Jeff.
column3: true

column2: It's been written off as such.
column3: It's been written off as such.

column2: It would be a great deal better for all concerned if it were left at that."
column3: It would be a great deal better for all concerned if it were left at that."
